headline: Anthony Injured as Knicks Fall to Memphis
summary: The Knicks played most of the second half without their superstar.

summary: Corrections & Amplifications

summary: See a sortable table showing the 126 U.S. stores that Delhaize Group said Thursday it would close.

headline: Correction
summary: The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, amassed much of its collection of South and Southeast Asian works in the early 20th century. The Dec. 29 Leisure & Arts story, "A Return to Earlier Ideals," said the collection began in the early 19th century.

summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: The Culture of the Wedding Gown
summary: Since 1934, more than 100,000 brides have come to Becker's Bridal in Fowler, Mich., to find their wedding gowns. Over the years, the store has adjusted to the influences of the wider culture.

headline: Price Check
summary: A search for the best fare on a Phoenix to Philadelphia round-trip flight in February shows how widely prices can vary among websites on a route where a lot of airlines compete.

headline: Photo Shows Apparent Desecration
summary: The U.S. military vowed to investigate a video that appears to show Marines urinating on dead Taliban militants

headline: Acacia to Acquire Adaptix for $160 Million
summary: Acacia Research agreed to buy Adaptix from private-equity firm Baker Capital for $160 million in cash, a move by Acacia to bulk up on its portfolio of next-generation wireless patents.

headline: Greece Scrambles to Complete Talks
summary: Greece's talks with private creditors on a debt write down plan are entering their final stage but key areas remain unresolved. Meanwhile, the country's budget deficit widened and the jobless rate rose.

headline: Hong Kong Indicts Deutsche Bank Director
summary: An antigraft agency formally charged Ma Sin-chi with accepting bribes linked to the trading of derivative warrants issued by Deutsche Bank.

headline: Beijing to Continue Property Curbs
summary: The Beijing municipal government will continue home-purchase restrictions this year to curb speculation and reduce prices, the city's mayor said.

headline: For Future Reference, a Pioneer in Online Reading
summary: Jerome Rubin, who died Monday at age 86, co-founded LexisNexis, the pioneering reference service that changed the way millions of lawyers, journalists and ordinary readers go about their daily routines.

headline: China's Rising Art Stars
summary: Here is a look at five promising Chinese contemporary artists. – Kelly Crow.

headline: Third Apparent Suicide in South Korea Bank Scandal
summary: The chairman of a small South Korean bank was found dead in what appeared to be the third suicide by the head of one of the nation's troubled savings banks in recent months.

headline: Manager Tung Shutting Avesta, Returning to Moore
summary: Hedge-fund manager William R. Tung told investors Thursday he would return their money and go back to his old firm, after two consecutive years of losses.

headline: RBS Bids to Shrink to Glory
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland's restructuring of its investment bank was one of the City's worst-kept secrets. The only surprise is that the overhaul isn't more radical.

headline: Nigerians Protest Gas Price Increase
summary: Tens of thousands of protesters marched through Nigeria's major cities on Thursday, chanting for President Goodluck Jonathan to resign.

headline: Galleon Prosecutor to Leave
summary: Assistant U.S. Attorney Jonathan Streeter is joining law firm Dechert LLP, the latest prosecutor to land a job defending white-collar defendants.

headline: Metabolix Loses ADM as Partner
summary: Biochemicals maker Metabolix said it will reduce its bioplastics business after ADM decided to pull out of the two companies' joint venture.

headline: Nike Contractor to Pay Back Wages to Workers
summary: An Indonesian factory that makes shoes under contract for sporting-goods giant Nike Inc. agreed to pay roughly $1 million in back wages, seeking to address allegations of workplace misconduct.

headline: UDR, MetLife Team Up to Buy Columbus Square
summary: UDR Inc. said Thursday that it formed a joint venture with MetLife Inc. that paid $630 million for Columbus Square, a complex of five high-rise apartment buildings on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

headline: Dimon Adds 2, Loses 1 to Key Panel
summary: J.P. Morgan Chase promoted two executives and added both to CEO James Dimon's closest adviser circle. But the bank's strategy and business development chief is leaving.

headline: Strong Demand for Spanish, Italian Debt
summary: Surprisingly strong auctions of Italian and Spanish debt pushed down bond yields from both countries and could bode well for a sale of longer-term Italian debt on Friday.

headline: SEC Weighs Two Picks for One Spot on Audit Board
summary: The agency is considering two finalists for a potentially key appointment to the government's audit-industry regulatory panel.

headline: Atlanta Tower Set for Foreclosure Auction
summary: Bank of America Plaza was bought at the market's peak and has struggled with rising vacancy rates and a heavy debt load in a tough office market.

headline: Program Trading
summary: Program trading in the week ended Jan. 6 amounted to 28.9% of New York Stock Exchange average daily volume of 1.60 billion shares, or 462.6 million program shares traded per day.

headline: Budget Gap Narrowed in Quarter
summary: The U.S. budget deficit in the first quarter of fiscal 2012 was smaller than in the same period a year earlier, as the federal government's finances improved slightly amid growth in the overall economy.

headline: Air France-KLM Starts Cost Cuts
summary: Air France-KLM is taking austerity steps as it tries to counter high fuel prices and weak traffic growth, but the company stopped short of politically sensitive cost-saving measures such as outright job cuts.

headline: Mortgage Rates Ease
summary: The 30-year fixed-rate mortgage averaged 3.89%, down from 3.91% the previous week.

headline: U.S. Raises Forecasts for Corn, Wheat Exports
summary: The U.S. is exporting more corn and wheat than expected, according to a report released by the Department of Agriculture, which also lowered estimates for domestic stockpiles of both commodities.

headline: Target to Test In-Store Boutiques
summary: Target is introducing "stores-within-stores" offering exclusive merchandise from several vendors. It is also testing special Apple Inc. displays.

headline: Europe's Oil Firms Cook Up a Treat
summary: European energy companies are expected to return more money to shareholders in 2012 as stubbornly high oil prices swell their balance sheets.

headline: Tesco Weighs on European Stocks
summary: Most European stock markets fell, as the retail sector came under heavy selling pressure after Tesco announced disappointing holiday trading sales. But well-received debt sales in Spain and Italy boosted banking shares.

headline: Crude Slumps Below $100
summary: Oil futures went on a late-day plunge below $100 a barrel after reports emerged saying the European Union's possible embargo of Iranian oil imports would likely be delayed up to six months.

headline: Gulf Issuers Turn to Sukuk
summary: Tighter funding conditions in Europe are pushing Middle East issuers to tap the still-liquid Islamic finance markets, with several debt sales announced since the start of the year and more likely to follow.

headline: Natural-Gas Futures Extend Slide
summary: Natural-gas futures extended losses for a fourth day, falling 2.8% to a fresh 28-month low of $2.697 per million British thermal units amid a growing surplus in gas in storage.

headline: Copper Reaches Two-Month High
summary: Copper futures climbed to the highest point in more than two months on hopes for steady Chinese demand and cautious optimism toward the euro zone.

headline: Detroit Bridge Owner Ordered Jailed
summary: Manuel "Matty" Moroun, the billionaire whose companies control Detroit's Ambassador Bridge, and a company executive were jailed for failing to comply with a court order to build roads that would route cross-border traffic out of a Detroit neighborhood.

headline: Rove: Romney Makes History
summary: South Carolina is the last chance for most of his rivals, but the front-runner needs to better answer the Bain attacks.

headline: Allstate Pay-Reporting Error Further Inflames Agents' Ire
summary: An Allstate system that shows agents how much they have earned in monthly commissions under-reported January payments this week, touching off a new uproar among the insurer's sales force.

headline: China Cracks Down on Financial Risk
summary: China's banking regulator took new steps to clamp down on risks in the financial sector, even as a report from S&P said political considerations might force authorities to grant banks some leeway on loans to local governments.

headline: Sears Hit As Lender Balks
summary: Struggling Sears Holdings Corp. suffered another setback when a large lender said it would no longer finance loans to suppliers awaiting payment from the company.

headline: Magna Steps Up Acquisition Hunt
summary: Auto parts maker Magna International is intensifying a global search for acquisition targets this year, pressured by customers to acquire financially troubled parts makers.

headline: Banesto Swings to Hefty Loss
summary: Banco Espanol de Credito became the first Spanish bank to heed the new government's request to stow more cash against bad real-estate loans, reporting a surprise fourth-quarter loss after booking an unexpectedly hefty $508.2 million worth of provisions.

headline: Will Newt Stand Down?
summary: The buzz is getting stronger that GOP presidential candidate Newt Gingrich will pull back on his planned $3 million ad campaign against Mitt Romney.

headline: Drug-Related Violence Soars in Mexico
summary: Drug-related violence in Mexico keeps rising, according to official statistics released Wednesday, suggesting the government of President Felipe Calderón is no closer to resolving a drug war that has killed close to 50,000 people.

headline: Hong Kong Resumes Live Poultry Imports
summary: Hong Kong authorities approved the resumption of imports and sales of live poultry Thursday, following a three-week ban imposed after a dead chicken tested positive for a lethal strain of bird flu.

headline: Japan to Reduce Iran Oil Imports
summary: Japan's finance minister said following a meeting with U.S. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner that Japan will take steps to reduce its dependency on oil imports from Iran, and work closely with the U.S. on the issue.

headline: Australian Open's Deep Field
summary: The Grand Slam tennis season is set to start with the Australian Open: a place for dominant players and underdogs to make their mark in the new year. We break down who has the best shot.

headline: Van der Sloot Admits Killing Peruvian Woman
summary: Joran Van der Sloot, an alleged suspect in the unsolved disappearance of U.S. student in the Caribbean, pleaded guilty to the 2010 murder of a young Peruvian woman.

headline: Banks Suing MBIA Press for Solvency Review
summary: Lawyers for Bank of America, UBS and others want the bond insurer's regulator for an independent evaluation of the firm's financial condition.

headline: Hon Hai Plant Dispute Is Resolved
summary: Microsoft and its partner Foxconn said that worker unrest at a Wuhan, China, plant earlier this month has been resolved and the majority of workers returned to work.

headline: Williams-Sonoma Lowers Guidance
summary: Williams-Sonoma lowered its full-year and fourth-quarter guidance, despite improved holiday sales.

headline: LME Defends New Fee
summary: The London Metal Exchange launched a defense of its decision to introduce a new user fee, saying there would be no review of the increase ahead of its planned March introduction.

summary: RHB Capital's planned takeover of OSK Holdings' financial services arm would propel RHB to become Malaysia's largest brokerage by market share.

summary: Global shipments of personal computers posted a rare quarterly decline, hurt by weak demand in the U.S. and Europe and a shortage of hard-disk drives that hobbled manufacturers.

summary: Royal Bank of Scotland unveiled a broad-ranging restructure in an attempt to scale back its investment-banking unit, which will see the bank shed a further 3,500 jobs over a three-year period.

headline: Top Japan Trust Bank Targets China
summary: The new president of Japan's leading trust bank hopes to seek further growth in China's still-developing bank-trust industry by offering financial services and products to local companies and wealthy individuals.

headline: Spain Grounds Airports Sale
summary: Spain's ambitious airport privatization plan is grounded while the new government reconsiders its options as bidders fret about the cost of borrowing to buy assets seen as overpriced.

headline: Canon Expects Gains as Its Business Diversifies
summary: Canon CEO Fujio Mitarai said the Japanese company's revenue target of $65 million by 2015 is "feasible" despite a challenging business environment, as Canon diversifies its camera and medical-technology operations.

headline: Slovakia: Allow Euro Members to Leave
summary: Europe has to weigh all scenarios for saving the euro, including the possibility of allowing member states to break away from the currency union, Slovak Finance Minister Ivan Miklos said.

headline: QBE Warns Earnings Could Halve
summary: Australia's biggest insurance company forecast that its 2011 earnings will plunge 40% to 50% following a late spike in catastrophe claims.

headline: Oldest Dr Pepper Bottler Settles Dispute
summary: The world's oldest bottler of Dr Pepper will stop distributing the popular soft drink after settling a trademark dispute with Dr Pepper Snapple Group.

summary: Kohl's is planning to further expand its New York City design office and add a new one on the West Coast to support its  strategy of focusing on exclusive brands.

headline: Fiesta, Not Fiasco, for Europe Bonds
summary: Euro-zone governments are finally getting a break, and Spain's latest auction of debt was particularly impressive. But Madrid can't afford to ease up on reform. The market will be watching its progress like a hawk.

headline: China Auto Sales Seen Up 8% This Year
summary: Auto-sales growth in China slowed to 2.5% in 2011—from 32% the year before—an industry group said, but will rebound to 8% this year.

headline: China Inflation Slowed Again in December
summary: Inflation in China slowed slightly in December, but was marginally above market expectations. The fifth straight month of moderating inflation gives Beijing more room to implement easing measures.

headline: Hudco Bond Likely Jan 27

headline: Trader: RBI Selling Dollars 'Aggressively'
summary: The Reserve Bank of India was seen selling dollars "aggressively" Thursday to support the rupee, a person familiar with the situation said.

headline: Monti Calls for Growth and Rigor
summary: Italian Prime Minister Mario Monti told lawmakers in his country that while Europe's fiscal laws are sacrosanct, more effort must be dedicated to boosting economic growth.

headline: India Shares Lose 0.9%
summary: Indian shares ended lower, led by declines in software stocks after bellwether Infosys sharply cut its dollar forecast for the fiscal year.

headline: Infosys' Nitty Gritties
summary: A favorable exchange rate can't mask deep challenges at India's Infosys.

headline: HDFC Profit Rises 10%
summary: Housing Development Finance Corp. missed analysts' estimates with a 10% rise in quarterly profit, as high interest costs and lower investment gains hurt India's biggest mortgage lender by assets.

summary: Credit Agricole is trying to unload millions of dollars in Asian loans held on its books at deep discounts, potentially driving up borrowing costs for some of the region's companies.

headline: Indonesia Holds Interest Rate

headline: Fitch Reiterates Stance on France

summary: A former Singapore-based Royal Bank of Scotland trader is suing the bank for wrongful termination after the group claimed he had improperly influenced the setting of benchmark interbank rates.

summary: Sainsbury posted improved fiscal third-quarter sales amid a strong Christmas season, as the U.K. supermarket chain benefited from a well-aimed marketing campaign.

headline: SsangYong to Build SUVs in India

headline: ING Axes European, Asian Offering
summary: Dutch financial-services company ING has dropped plans to float its insurance and investment-management operations in Europe and Asia due to the uncertain economic outlook and turbulent financial markets.

headline: German Consumer Prices Rise
summary: Consumer prices in Germany rose 0.7% month-to-month in December and 2.1% from a year earlier, data from the federal statistics office confirmed.

headline: India Industrial Output Rebounds
summary: India's industrial output rose in November, bouncing back from a dismal reading the previous month and lessening the urgency for the central bank to begin loosening monetary policy.

headline: Japan Warns of Volcker Rule's Impact

headline: Exports, Not Politics, Determine Taiwan's Growth
summary: For Taiwan's economy, it's foreign demand not domestic politics that is the decisive factor.

headline: India Food Prices Decline

headline: China Minsheng Bank Profit Growth to Slow
summary: China Minshg Banking expects stable profit growth in 2012 on strong income from smaller loans, but it won't maintain the blistering growth pace of 2011.

headline: Forecasting the Markets in 2012
summary: Experts are busy telling us how gold or stocks will perform this year, but avoiding them could help you make better investment decisions, says Shefali Anand.

summary: Hindu devotees walk in India, police shield themselves from a molotov cocktail in the Philippines, China releases six pandas into semi-wild enclosures and more.

headline: Photos of the Day: Jan. 12
summary: In today's pictures, a child dresses up as a god in India, displaced people wait for food rations in South Sudan, a soldier stands guard at the Kremlin Wall, and more.

headline: Texas May Enforce Abortion Law
summary: The Fifth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld a Texas law that requires women seeking an abortion to have a sonogram exam and to listen to a physician's detailed description of the fetus.

headline: Buyout Weighed for German Retailer
summary: Leveraged-buyout firms including Apax Partners are in talks with the founding family of Douglas Holding to potentially take the German retailer private.

headline: Green Bay Coach's Loss Casts Pall Over Game
summary: The death of Joe Philbin's son serves as a stark reminder to both the Giants and the Packers that life is about more than football.

summary: Here are today's top business stories from the Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Romney Problem Is the Bain of Wall Street
summary: Until now, there hasn't been a national discussion about whether the private-equity industry is a healthy parasite serving the national economic good or simply sucks wealth from our economy to a privileged few, writes David Weidner.

headline: Traders' New Cry: See You in a Week
summary: Demand is soaring for stock options that expire within a week's time, as opposed to the usual monthly expiration

headline: U.S. Plans New Push for Talks With Taliban
summary: The U.S. plans a major push next week to jump-start peace talks with the Taliban amid the first concrete signs of progress toward a negotiated end to the 10-year-old war in Afghanistan.

headline: Parents Try to Enact Trigger Law
summary: Disgruntled parents at Desert Trails Elementary School near Los Angeles plan to use a powerful and controversial law, known as Parent Trigger, to force the district to overhaul their low-performing school or to turn it into a charter school that they would run.

headline: Elliott Abrams: A Year for Elections, Not Mideast Peace
summary: Obama will trumpet his commitment to Israel while wondering if it will attack Iran.

headline: Greatness Is a Hard Thing to Predict
summary: Like most Americans, Kimberley Strassel ("Mr. Good Enough," op-ed, Jan. 3) seems to search for a giant for the times and finds no one who measures up. But she and we ignore a basic fact of life: a national leader cannot be a giant until after the fact.

headline: Goldman Vets Exit in Sign of Times
summary: In a surprising shake-up, two of the four executives in charge of Goldman Sachs's securities division will leave the company as it struggles with a downturn in its huge trading operation.

headline: Westchester County Colonial
summary: Built 100 years ago, this Colonial furnished with European antiques was renovated by the current owners to enclose two porches and upgrade the kitchen.

headline: Many Borough Views From Dumbo
summary: Krystal Jin has a Brooklyn penthouse with three-borough views and staircases imported from China.

headline: Baby Salsa Dance? Giants' Cruz Is a Daddy
summary: Also: Former Jets lineman Damien Woody jumps on the Mark Sanchez pileup, and one-time Mets prospect Fernando Martinez is claimed by the Houston Astros.

headline: Google Renews Push in China
summary: Google is stepping up expansion efforts in China despite its confrontation with authorities there two years ago, in an acknowledgment by the Web-search giant that it can't afford to miss out on the world's biggest Internet market.

headline: Some Left Out as  Corridor Shines
summary: Crime is down and business is up in the Divisadero Corridor, but the area is dealing with some of the same gentrification issues that the Mission has faced in recent years.

summary: Bank of America has placed its advertising account on review, as it tries to recover from several years of corporate crises and public-relations blunders.

summary: Countries from Brazil to the Philippines are pouring into the bond market, taking advantage of soaring investor demand to sell debt at record-low interest rates.

headline: Fred Barnes: Romney and the Corporate Raider Critique
summary: The front-runner needs an idea bigger than himself. How about tax reform?

summary: Astronomers said each star in the Milky Way probably has at least one companion planet, adding credence to the notion that planets are as common in the cosmos as grains of sand on the beach.

summary: Germany's E.ON agreed to acquire a stake in Brazil's MPX Energia in a deal that will have the companies invest billions of dollars in new South American power plants.

summary: A panel investigating allegations that Florida Democratic Rep. Hastings sexually harassed a staff member said in a report that the House Committee on Ethics should review the allegations.

summary: Tagg, a small GPS device, is designed to help owners track down stray pets.

headline: Edwin Feulner: A Step Backward for Economic Freedom in 2012

headline: Killing of Scientist Stokes U.S.-Iran Tensions

headline: Oakland Seeks a Lift From Pop-Ups

summary: Fashion reporter Teri Agins answers readers' questions.

headline: A 19th-Century Victorian, With a View
summary: This Petaluma Victorian, asking $799,000, dates to 1882, according to the owners. They say the home has the original trim and a space behind a trap door where previous residents stowed liquor during Prohibition.

headline: MF Global Customers Face Red Tape
summary: Customers are in a new stage of recovery for the rest of their money, slogging through what some describe as an unduly arduous claims process.

summary: Odds are that even the top pick in Thursday's Major League Soccer draft won't become a big-time player.

headline: Vital Signs
summary: Homicides were up considerably last year in Oakland and San Jose—with a sharp rise in gang-related killings—though they stayed at a historical low in San Francisco.

summary: At the age of 80, Regis Philbin remains a crafty tennis player. His stroke is clean and steady, and despite heart bypass surgery and a titanium hip, there is unexpected power.

summary: Wall Street pay is set to be reduced after a dismal year but the cuts won't spare banking chiefs from potentially bruising encounters with investors during coming shareholders meetings.

summary: People familiar with the Cuomo administration's thinking said the governor won't pursue repealing a law that keeps public-employee union contracts in effect even after they expire.

summary: Coca-Cola admitted it had discovered an unapproved fungicide in orange juice products sold by it and some competitors in the U.S.

summary: The annual National Board of Review dinner is known for the big time celebrities who pop in on their way to the next few weeks of awards season campaigning, hand-wringing and glad-handling.

summary: Fashion reporter Teri Agins answers readers' questions.

headline: Federal Wealth Tax Would Certainly Change the Game
summary: Prof. Ronald McKinnon's suggestion ("The Conservative Case for a Wealth Tax," op-ed, Jan. 9) that a modest wealth tax can be a conservative policy tool is mistaken. Governments use new tools of taxation to grow spending, the reason conservatives oppose a value-added tax

summary: San Francisco's Financial District has many options for luxury dining and casual eats. Perbacco is the rare restaurant that offers both.

summary: Pakistani Prime Minister Yousuf Raza Gilani fired his defense secretary just hours after the nation's military warned that Gilani's recent attacks on the army chief could have "grievous consequences."

headline: Economists See Europe as Main Threat to U.S. Growth

headline: Photos of the Day: Jan. 11
summary: In today's pictures, demonstrators in the Philippines are sprayed with water, young Haitian earthquake survivors play, men transport chairs on tricycles in China, and more.

headline: Parents Rebel Against California School
summary: Fed-up parents of students attending a low-performing school in Southern California aim to use the power given to them by the state to take an unusual step: fire the school.
